message:
i see a rising wave of DDoS as a protest  , there is eve a petition on the whitehouse to legalize DDos in general 
(https://petitions.whitehouse.gov/petition/make-distributed-denial-service-ddos-legal-form-protesting) 

so in what conditions do you think an act of DDos can be legal in Egypt  ?
story: Mohamed Abdel Aty shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Angry Thai Internet users 'bring down ICT website' - The Nation
caption: nationmultimedia.com
description: Angry Thai Internet users 'bring down ICT website' The Nation Government Spokesman Maj General Sansern Kaewkamnerd told Nation TV that the collapse of Information and Communications Technology Ministry website...

data.message: There are no cases where it can be legal. Compare it to someone deciding you cannot enter your house. Would you like that?

Sherif Omar  houses are private  , websites are public and in case of government website it is considered a public service which in some laws it is allowed to protest against 

check out the statement from the link below 

"There is a legal precedent for such comparisons. In May 2006, a court in Germany, was asked if a DDoS blockade of Lufthansa for allowing its planes to be used in the deportation of asylum-seekers was in fact a demonstration. The Frankfurt appeals court ruled that the 2001 DDoS attack against Lufthansa that was also accompanied by a sit-in at the company’s headquarters, did not violate German law."

http://www.hackersunited.com/tag/lufthansa/

Using DDoS as a form of protest has been going for a few years, it was used by AnonOps during the "arab spring" ... and there were various attempts by OpEgypt during Jan 25, none of them were that effective though as far as I've seen.
